items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Lambourn Valley catchment
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. The catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Candovers and Old Alresford
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and relatively stable after a monthâ€™s rain (59mm) has been recorded at Bishops Sutton in the last week. At Preston Candover, the level is 7cm lower than this time last week. At Old Alresford the level is 12cm lower. Cellar flooding is expected to be affecting properties in the Candovers, Northington, and Old Alresford. In Old Alresford, internal ground floor flooding is affecting isolated properties. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively in all locations. From today (02/05/2024) to Monday (06/05/2024), further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels are expected to remain relatively stable or could even rise slightly. However, they are expected to begin slowly falling again within the next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday (09/05/2024).

items.description: River Kennet from Thatcham down to Reading
items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels are falling slowly on the lower River Kennet following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible over the following days. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Pitton, West Tytherley, Nether Wallop and Broughton
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high. At Lopcombe Corner, the level has fallen by 2m in the last week. At West Tytherley, the level has fallen by 12cm, and at Pitton by 40cm. Over the last week, 28mm of rain was recorded at Broughton. In Pitton, residual water may be affecting cellars and roads, and sewerage network impacts may still be occurring. In West Tytherley village, cellar, land and road flooding is expected to be ongoing, and septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From Tuesday (07/05/2024) to Saturday (11/05/2024), high pressure with more settled, drier weather is expected across Hampshire. We expect groundwater levels to carry on slowly falling. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 14/05/2024.

items.description: River Kennet and its tributaries from Berwick Bassett down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Kennet, River Og, River Aldbourne, Froxfield Stream, River Dun, River Shalbourne

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels remain high on the River Kennet following recent rainfall and high groundwater. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible over the coming days. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Windrush from Bourton to Newbridge
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high but stable on the River Windrush following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible over the next few days. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Henley and Assendon area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but stable at our Stonor borehole near Henley and Assendon. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few weeks. Groundwater levels remain sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We have staff in the area checking impacts on the ground and we are continuing to monitor groundwater levels. We will update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Ginge Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high the Ginge Brook following rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is possible over the coming days. The forecast for this week remains unsettled. River levels are expected to continue gradually falling but will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Dean, Singleton, Charlton, East Dean and Chilgrove
items.message: Groundwater is high, within 120cm of the surface at the East Dean borehole, but slowly falling a few centimetres each day. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, affecting the ability of the sewage network to operate in East Dean, Charlton, Singleton and West Dean. Water will affect some basements, and be underneath ground floors. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. Groundwater should continue to slowly fall, but minor flood impacts affecting the sewage network could continue through to mid May. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 10/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Twyford and Hensting
items.message: Groundwater levels in Twyford and Hensting are high, but slowly falling. Over the last week, 27mm of rainfall was recorded at Otterbourne. A small number of properties in Twyford and Hensting are currently being affected by cellar flooding. Water continues to affect Hensting Lane. From Tuesday (07/05/2024) to Saturday (11/05/2024), high pressure with more settled, drier weather is expected across Hampshire. We expect groundwater levels to carry on slowly falling. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 14/05/2024.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is still higher than normal, but now slowly falling. High pressure, settled weather, and no rain is forecast for the next five days. Minor flood impacts affecting fields near Shripney Lane and the A259, parts of the Tesco car park on Shripney Road and land around caravans at Riverside Caravan Centre will continue to ease over the week ahead. Water levels will fall slowly, only twenty centimetres over the next five days. There is a suggestion that rain or showers could return next week. Please remain prepared, while river levels are higher than normal, and keep flood protection products ready as a precaution, if you have them. Our pumps at Felpham are running to reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is possible.

items.description: Colne Brook at Iver and Colnbrook

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the Colne Brook and Lower Colne due to recent heavy rainfall.

Today, Tuesday 7th May, is forecast to be dry.

We will continue to monitor river levels closely.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th May, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Thame, Horsenden Stream and Chalgrove Brook

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Thame, Horsenden Stream, Chalgrove Brook

items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high on the River Thame following recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today, 03/05/2024, in the lower River Thame around Stadhampton. Further rain is possible today, which has the potential to be heavy at times. The weekend is likely to mostly dry, however there is a chance of showers developing on Sunday. River levels are expected to remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.
We are monitoring the situation. Do not drive through flood water and avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 04/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Pang from East Ilsley to Pangbourne and Sulham Brook
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high on the River Pang following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible over the coming days. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to continue gradually falling, but will remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln and its tributaries
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected. 
River levels are high on the River Coln following rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue over the following days, especially in the Fairford area. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Lower River Colne and Frays River

floodArea.county: Buckinghamshire, Greater London, Hertfordshire, Hillingdon, Slough, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message:
River levels remain high on the River Colne, Frays, Wraysbury, and Poyle Channel.

No further significant rainfall is forecast today, Tuesday 7th May.

We will continue to monitor river levels closely.

Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.

This message will be updated by 10am tomorrow, Wednesday 8th May, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Vernham Dean, Upton and the Bourne Valley
items.message: Groundwater levels in the Bourne Valley are high but slowly falling. During the last week, half a monthâ€™s rain (30mm) was recorded at Andover. We expect a small number of properties in Upton and Hurstbourne Tarrant will be experiencing cellar flooding. In Upton, water continues to affect the main road. Impacts to the sewerage network and septic tanks are ongoing throughout the valley. From today (01/05/2024) to Friday (03/05/2024), heavy rain is forecast in Hampshire with between 25 and 50mm of rain possible in these three days. Groundwater levels are expected to initially continue falling, but could begin to stabilise or even rise next week if heavy rain affects the Bourne Valley. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday (08/05/2024).

items.description: Groundwater flooding in West Ilsley, East Ilsley, Compton, Chilton and West Hagbourne
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Hodcott borehole near West Ilsley, East Ilsley and Compton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. Groundwater levels are currently falling slowly, but the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne
items.message: Groundwater levels in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne are high but relatively stable after a monthâ€™s rain (54mm) has been recorded in the last week at Broughton. However, levels are currently 14cm lower than this time last week. Cellar flooding to a small number of properties in Kings Somborne and Little Somborne is expected to be ongoing. Road flooding impacts are ongoing. From today (02/05/2024) to Monday (06/05/2024), further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels are likely to stay relatively stable and could rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall. However, levels are expected to continue decreasing within days after this. Groundwater flooding impacts are expected to continue for at least another 10 days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday (09/05/2024).

items.description: River Lambourn and its tributaries from Upper Lambourn down to Newbury

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Lambourn, Great Shefford Stream, Winterbourne Stream

items.message:
Property flooding is not expected. 
River levels on the Lambourn and its tributaries are high due to high groundwater levels and recent rainfall. Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected to continue today and in the days to come, especially in areas closest to the River Lambourn in Newbury and on the Winterbourne in the Bagnor area. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high over the coming days and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bishops Sutton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bishops Sutton are high, and they are rising and falling with each rainfall event. In the last week, a monthâ€™s rain (59mm) has been recorded in Bishops Sutton. We expect properties in Bishops Sutton will be experiencing cellar flooding. Isolated properties may still have residual flood water affecting the ground floor of their properties. Roads (such as the B3047) will be flooded, particularly after heavy rainfall. Impacts to septic tanks are ongoing. From today (02/05/2024) to Monday (06/05/2024), further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels will rise and fall in response to any heavy rainfall recorded, but levels are expected to continue falling within the next week. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday (09/05/2024).

items.description: Groundwater flooding in villages surrounding Andover
items.message: Groundwater levels are high and slowly falling. During the last week, half a monthâ€™s rain (30mm) was recorded at Andover. We expect that cellar flooding is ongoing in Appleshaw, Hatherden, Penton Grafton and Penton Mewsey. Road flooding is occurring to the main road into Penton Grafton and the road from Biddesden to Appleshaw. Sewerage network and septic tank impacts are ongoing across most villages. From today (01/05/2024) to Friday (03/05/2024), heavy rain is forecast in Hampshire, with between 25 and 50mm of rain possible in these three days. Along the river corridors, we expect groundwater levels to rise slightly after each heavy rainfall event. At Clanville borehole, levels are expected to continue falling initially, but could begin to stabilise or even rise within the next week if heavy rain affects the area. If this occurs groundwater levels within the valleys are then expected to rise again. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. Please ensure any pumps used to reduce water levels are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday (08/05/2024).

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle
items.message: Groundwater levels in Finchdean, Dean Lane End and Rowlands Castle are high and slowly falling. At Finchdean, the level has fallen by 19cm in the last week. More than half a monthâ€™s rain (40mm) was recorded at Walderton during that time. Pumps which prevent water from entering property may still be required. Residual water may still be affecting roads. Surface water may flood property during heavier rainfall events. From today (01/05/2024) to Friday (03/05/2024), heavy rain is forecast in Hampshire with between 25 and 50mm of rain possible in these three days. In Finchdean we expect the groundwater level to rise slightly after each heavy rainfall event. At the borehole in Chalton, levels are expected to continue falling initially, but could begin to stabilise if heavy rain affects the area. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operational. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Wednesday (08/05/2024).

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Bramdean and Cheriton
items.message: Groundwater levels in Bramdean and Cheriton are high but falling slowly. In the last week, the level at Cheriton Wood has fallen by 31cm. We expect isolated properties in Cheriton will be affected by cellar flooding. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From today (02/05/2024) to Monday (06/05/2024), further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels may stabilise, or even rise slightly, in response to the recent heavy rainfall, but they will likely continue falling again within a few days. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday (09/05/2024).

items.description: Tidal Thames riverside from Putney Bridge to Teddington Weir
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Greater London, Hammersmith and Fulham, Hounslow, Richmond upon Thames, Wandsworth

items.message:
River levels are expected to be high as a result of spring tides.

The forecast high tide at Richmond is 4.72mAOD at 14:00 on 07/05/24 and 4.60mAOD at 02:00 on 08/05/24.

Flooding of low-lying roads and footpaths is expected, which may exist for one to two hours either side of high tide. Flooding of properties is not expected.

We believe there is a possibility of flooding for Putney Embankment (SW15), Chiswick Mall and Strand on the Green (W4), Thames Bank at Mortlake (SW14), Ranelagh Drive (TW1), Friars Lane and Water Lane (TW9), Riverside and The Embankment at Twickenham, and the Towpath below Teddington Lock. 

Astronomical tide levels are rising. The river flow at Teddington Weir is high for this time of year at 124 cubic metres per second and is rising. We anticipate the flows to remain high for the next few days.

We are closely monitoring the situation.

This message will be updated by 09:00 on 08/05/24, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Alton area
items.message:
Groundwater levels remain high at our Farringdon borehole near Alton. Groundwater levels remain above normal levels for this time of year and are currently stabilised at this level. The catchment remains sensitive to rainfall due to the saturated ground and levels may start to increase again if we receive further rainfall. Low lying land, gardens, roads and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

An overall stabilising trend is expected as we move out of the winter period. However, any heavy rainfall may change the trends and prolong high levels or cause levels to rise again. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on 07/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hursley
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hursley are high and relatively stable after a monthâ€™s rain (54mm) has been recorded at Otterbourne in the last week. However, levels are currently 8cm lower than this time last week. We expect widespread cellar flooding impacts to be ongoing. Sewerage system impacts are continuing through the village. From today (02/05/2024) to Monday (06/05/2024), further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels are expected to remain relatively stable and could rise slightly in response to heavy rainfall. However, they are then expected to continue falling again within a few days. Groundwater flooding impacts in Hursley are expected to continue throughout May and possibly into June. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Thursday (09/05/2024).

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Deane and Ashe in North Hampshire
items.message: Groundwater levels in Deane and Ashe remain high but are slowly falling. Over the last week, 21mm of rainfall was recorded at Overton. At our borehole in Oakley, the level has fallen by 30cm. We expect properties in Deane to be pumping water from their cellars. Groundwater spring flows are impacting land and roads. The access road from the B3400 into Deane (at Deane Park) is closed. Septic tanks will be struggling to operate effectively. From Tuesday (07/05/2024) to Saturday (11/05/2024), high pressure with more settled, drier weather is expected across Hampshire. We expect groundwater levels to carry on slowly falling. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. If you have pumps to help reduce water levels, please ensure that they are operating. This Flood Alert will be updated by 18:00 on Tuesday 14/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Kimpton and Lilley Bottom
items.message:
Groundwater levels have responded to high Autumn and Winter rainfall and have risen to high levels at our observation borehole at Lilley Bottom. 

Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities in the Kimpton and Lilley Bottom area are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. 

Though levels have declined slightly during the last few weeks we expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks in response to the high winter rainfall. Low lying lands and roads will therefore be at risk of flooding. 

Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 8th May 2024 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Flamstead
items.message: Groundwater levels have responded to high Autumn and Winter rainfall and have risen to very high levels at our observation borehole at River Hill close to Flamstead. Groundwater levels are unusually high for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities are at risk of being affected by flooding from groundwater. Though levels have declined slightly since their late February peak we expect levels to remain high over the coming weeks. Low lying lands and roads such as those in the Trowley Bottom area near Flamstead will therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater behaviour this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message on Wednesday 8th May, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Hambledon
items.message: Groundwater levels in Hambledon are high but slowly falling. At our borehole at Whitedale Farm, the level has fallen by 2.84m in the last week. During this time, a monthâ€™s rain (54mm) has been recorded at Worlds End. Only minimal groundwater flooding impacts are expected to roads and the sewerage system. From today 02/05/2024 to Monday 06/05/2024, further spells of rain, some of which may be heavy, are forecast in Hampshire with between 10 and 50mm possible during this time. Groundwater levels are expected to continue falling initially, but could begin rising again next week if heavy rain affects Hambledon. If levels continue falling, and dry weather is forecast next week, this Flood Alert will be removed. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We advise residents to remain prepared while heavy rain continues to affect Hambledon. This Flood Alert will be updated or removed by 18:00 on Thursday 09/05/2024.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Newmarket
items.message: A flood alert has been issued. Groundwater levels are falling steadily but remain high following prolonged wet weather. Flooding is still possible. This message applies to areas of Newmarket at risk of groundwater flooding, including the High Street, and the A14 eastbound between junction 37 at Newmarket and junction 38 at Red Lodge. Be ready to take action to protect your property. We are monitoring the situation and are not expecting it to escalate. We will update this message by 11am Wednesday 8th May 2024, or as the situation changes.â€¯

items.description: Nailbourne and Little Stour
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Little Stour, Nailbourne, River Wingham, River Stour

items.message:
River levels have fallen slightly on the Little Stour and Nailbourne during April but flooding may continue to affect low lying land and roads along the Nailbourne around Elham, Barham, Bridge and Bekesbourne, and on the Little Stour around Littlebourne and Wickhambreux. Please avoid driving or walking through floodwater.
As of Thursday 2 May 2024, the forecast is for localised storms and showers over the weekend with drier conditions following by the middle of next week. We are actively monitoring the situation, liaising with partners, and our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. The Littlebourne Flood Relief channel is operating.
This message will be updated by 6pm on Thursday 9 May 2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Kent have shown a slow but steady decline during April. The Alkham Bourne and the Nailbourne between Lyminge and Littlebourne are still flowing. Localised flooding will continue to affect low-lying land, roads, and water infrastructure around the Elham Valley, Alkham and Petham. Other communities in East Kent may also be impacted. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water. As of Thursday 2 May, the forecast is for localised storms and showers over the weekend with drier conditions following by the middle of next week.
We are monitoring the situation and are working with local authorities and communities with the deployment of temporary defences, such as Canterbury City Councilâ€™s temporary defences in Barham and the Littlebourne Flood Relief channel. Our staff are maintaining and clearing key structures. 
This message will be updated by 6pm on Friday 10th May 2024. Search 'Kent Groundwater situation' on gov.uk for more information.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in South East London
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.county: Barking and Dagenham, Bexley, Bromley, Croydon, Greater London, Greenwich, Havering, Kent, Kingston upon Thames, Lambeth, Lewisham, Merton, Newham, Southwark, Surrey, Sutton, Wandsworth

items.message:
Groundwater levels in East Surrey and South London rose during the winter following higher than average rainfall. Levels continued to increase until the second half of March in response to heavy rainfall and have remained high in April. The Caterham Bourne is in flow since mid-March and is still flowing in the Whyteleafe and Kenley area and the Environment Agency is monitoring the levels and flow of the Bourne in Kenley Bourne Park. Some properties with deep basements in and around Purley and low lying land near the Caterham Bourne could still experience flooding. 

Riparian owners are reminded to keep clear the sections of river that flow through their land. Flooding of properties, gardens and low lying land elsewhere is not expected at this point in time. The Environment Agency is monitoring the situation alongside Surrey County Council, Tandridge District Council and the London Borough of Croydon. We will update this message on Thursday 15 May 2024, or sooner if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Leckhampstead area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but slowly falling at our Chapel Wood borehole in the Leckhampstead area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. The catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the Great Shefford area
items.message: Groundwater levels are high but currently stable at our Northfield Farm borehole in the Great Shefford area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and are at a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. Groundwater levels are steady, but the catchment remains sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars will therefore continue to be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We have staff in the area checking  impacts on the ground and we are continuing to monitor groundwater levels. We will update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in upper River Ems Valley
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface at the Compton borehole, but over ten metres lower than during winter, and falling thirty centimetres each day. Minor groundwater flood impacts are expected to continue, with springs affecting fields, and water on roads including Stoughton main road and the road from East Marden. Groundwater could affect a small number of properties close to the village green Stoughton, and possibly basements of properties in Walderton too. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. Groundwater will still not fall fast, with minor flood impacts potentially persisting until mid May. If you have pumps to help reduce groundwater levels in your property, ensure they are operational. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 18:00 10/05/2024.

items.description: River Maun in Nottinghamshire
items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  

The risk of flooding from thunderstorms has now passed.  No further rainfall is forecast.  

We continue to monitor the situation.  

Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

items.description: River Wye and The Hughenden Stream
items.message:
Property flooding is not currently expected.
River levels are high but stable on the Hughenden Stream following recent rainfall and high groundwater levels. Flooding of low lying land and roads remains possible, especially in areas closest to the Hughenden Stream in High Wycombe. The forecast for this week remains unsettled, with the potential for heavy showers at times. River levels are expected to remain high and will be sensitive to further rainfall.
We are closely monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated on Friday 10/05/2024, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Cuckmere River
items.message: River levels through Hellingly and Alfriston are still higher than normal following Monday's rain, but are currently falling. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, rural roads, and gardens in Hellingly should continue to ease. The incoming tide at 11:00 (07/05/2024) will raise river levels in Alfriston, where minor flooding will continue to affect fields and gardens near North Street, Willows Car Park and River Lane. From 14:00 (07/05/2024), water levels in Alfriston will also fall. River levels should return nearer to normal by Wednesday evening (08/05/2024). While river levels are still higher than normal, please plan to avoid driving through routes susceptible to flooding, including Mill Lane and Church Road, Hellingly and North Street Alfriston. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is possible.

items.description: Rivers Eden and Eden Brook
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high, but are starting to fall on the Rivers Eden and Eden Brook due to heavy rainfall yesterday Monday 06/05/2024. Areas most at risk include low lying land and roads close to the rivers, particularly on and around Water Lane and Haxted Road. No further rainfall is forecast. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 16:00 PM on Tuesday 07/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Mole and its tributaries from Kinnersley Manor to South Hersham
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message: River levels remain high but are beginning to fall on the River Mole. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Mole, with low lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around areas between Kinnersley Manor and Sidlow, although there may be other areas of minor flooding. No further rainfall is forecast today.  We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 07/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high in all locations, and still slowly rising in Barcombe, following Monday's rain. The Anchor Inn, and isolated properties at Barcombe Mills are expected to be affected by flooding. Anchor Lane, Barcombe Mills Road, Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will be impassable. Nearer Ardingly, river levels are slowly falling, but flood impacts will continue to affect properties at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield, and cottages and farm buildings on Sloop Lane, as well as fields, rural roads and gardens all along the Ouse. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. Near Ardingly, flood impacts should ease by 18:00 (07/05/2024). Near Barcombe the river will not begin to fall until 13:00 (07/05/2024). River levels will remain higher than normal until Wednesday. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding such as Barcombe Mills Road. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock and Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely. We will update this message by 12:00 on 08/05/2024.

items.description: Lower Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and rising, following Monday's rain. The lower River Ouse will be higher than normal, and near the tops of the banks. From 10:30 07/05/2024, flooding could again affect fields, rural roads and gardens of Whitfeld Lane and Ivors Lane, Hamsey. In Lewes, a small amount of water could affect Railway Lane, Eastgate Wharf, near the Fire Station and the Pells area and gardens of Riverdale and Malling Deanery near Willeys Bridge. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. As the tide falls, from 14:00 Tuesday afternoon 07/05/2024, the Lower Ouse should also fall. However, minor flood impacts will again occur over Tuesday evening's tide between 23:00 07/05/2024 and 03:00 08/05/2024. The peak water levels should begin to fall from Wednesday evening 08/05/2024. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 08/05/2024.

items.description: Chertsey Bourne

floodArea.county: Bracknell Forest, Surrey, Windsor and Maidenhead

items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels had risen on the Chertsey Bourne as a result of a period of heavy rainfall but have now levelled off. No further flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 07/05/24. Today's forecast is for sunny spells with some scattered showers, with drier weather forecast for the rest of the week. River levels are forecast to remain high but stable over the next few days. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 08/05/24, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in the High Wycombe area
items.message: Groundwater levels remain high but are falling very slowly at our Piddington Ray Farm borehole in the High Wycombe area. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have reached a level where communities may continue to be affected by groundwater flooding. Groundwater levels remain sensitive to further rainfall due to saturated ground and high groundwater levels. Low-lying land, gardens, roads, and cellars may therefore be at risk of flooding. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. Avoid driving or walking through floodwater as there may be concealed hazards. We are continuing to monitor groundwater levels and will update this message next week by 10/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Upper River Wey
items.message: Property flooding is not currently expected. River levels are rising on the River Wey following yesterday's  heavy rainfall.  Flooding of low lying land and roads is expected today, 07/05/24, especially in the Godalming area. Today's forecast is for  sunny spells with some scattered showers, with drier weather forecast for the rest of the week. We are monitoring the situation. Avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. Go to the 'River and Sea levels in England' webpage for current river levels. This message will be updated by tomorrow morning, 08/05/24, or before if the situation changes.

items.description: Ings Beck and Oakenshaw Beck

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ings Beck, Alverthorpe Beck, Balne Beck, Oakenshaw Beck

items.message:
Levels in the Ings Beck catchment have fallen significantly overnight and are no longer a cause for concern. No further impactful rainfall is forecast over the next few days and the becks are predicted to return to normal levels. We will continue to monitor the situation. Our operational staff will be out checking flood defences and clearing trash screens following the high river levels. Any issues of concern can be reported on our Incident Hotline on 0800 80 70 60.
 
Surface water following yesterday's thunderstorms is likely to affect low spots on roads today. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water, which can contain hidden hazards.

items.description: Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams are now falling following Monday's rain. River levels have fallen by half a metre, and should now be lower than the tops of the river banks. Rain has cleared the area, and the forecast is for high pressure, bringing settled and dry weather for the next five days. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens should continue to ease overnight. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river on Bridge Road or Hickmans Lane, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. We will clear debris from grilles through Lindfield, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will re-issue this message if new instances of property flooding are possible.

items.description: Lindfield on the Scrase Bridge and West Common Streams

floodArea.riverOrSea: Scrase Bridge Stream, West Common Stream

items.message: The Scrasebridge and West Common Streams are now falling following Monday's rain. River levels have fallen by half a metre, and should now be lower than the tops of the river banks. If you see a blockage affecting the flow in the river on Bridge Road or Hickmans Lane, please call our incident hotline on 0800 80 70 60. items.description: River Adur East Branch
items.message: The River Adur is very high following Monday's rain, but is now slowly falling. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Mock Bridge, near Shermanbury as well as the A281 at Mock Bridge. There will be extensive water in fields. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring dry and settled weather. The river will continue to fall. Flood impacts will begin to ease from 17:00 (07/05/2024), however, it might be Wednesday (08/05/2024) before river levels and flood risk have fallen significantly. Some roads, including the A281 at Mock Bridge, may remain impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 11:00 on 08/05/2024.

items.description: Upper River Mole, Ifield Brook, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex

floodArea.riverOrSea: Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream, Burstow Stream

items.message: River levels are now falling steadily on the Ifield Brook, River Mole, Gatwick Stream and Burstow Stream. The forecast is dry for this morning. No further flooding to fields and roads is expected, however there may be standing water seen for several days. We are monitoring rainfall and river levels and are checking rivers for blockages in the area. We will continue to monitor levels closely. Avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water. This message will be updated by 5:00 PM on 07/05/2024, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Lindfield Bridge on the River Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is very high, but now slowly falling following Monday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties at Bridge Cottage and Dean's Water Mill at Lindfield Bridge on the B2028 near Lindfield. Flood water will also be extensive through fields, and affect rural roads and gardens. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. The river should continue to fall. Flood impacts should ease a little by 17:00 07/05/2024, but river levels will not return nearer to normal until 10:00 08/05/2024. Riverside properties at Dean's Water Mill and Lindfield Bridge are encouraged to keep flood protection products installed if you have them. We are operating our structures at Pimms Lock, to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 12:00 08/05/2024.

items.description: Upper Arun
items.message: The River Arun is still high, following Monday's rain. Between Billingshurst and Pulborough river levels are still rising. Nearer Horsham and Broadbridge Heath, river levels are now falling. Minor flooding will continue to affect fields, gardens, and roads all along the upper River Arun. Including grassy areas and gardens of Tanbridge Park and Blackbridge Court and fields behind Arunside in Horsham. Flood water will also continue to affect fields and gardens of isolated mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Pallingham Quay. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. By 14:00 07/05/2024, the river should have fallen nearer to normal in Horsham, and begun to fall near Pallingham Quay. However, near Pulborough, river levels could be higher than normal until Thursday afternoon. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Wanford, if you have them. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to help reduce the risk of flooding in Horsham. We will update this message by 12:00 08/05/2024.

items.description: River Adur West Branch
items.message: The River Adur has fallen significantly and continues to fall following Monday's rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields and rural roads between Coolham and Henfield will continue to ease through Tuesday. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. The river should return to a more normal level by Wednesday (08/05/2024). Some roads, including the Coolham Road at Slaughter Bridge, may still be affected by flood water. Please take care driving on routes vulnerable to flooding. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will re-issue this Flood Alert if property flooding is possible.

items.message:

Surface water following yesterday's thunderstorms is likely to affect low spots on roads today. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water, which can contain hidden hazards.

items.description: Barcombe Mills on the River Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is high and still slowly rising in Barcombe, following Monday's rain. Flooding is expected to continue to affect the Anchor Inn, near Barcombe, and isolated properties in Barcombe Mills. Barcombe Mills road and Anchor Lane are expected to be impassable. Flood water will be extensive through fields. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. The river should begin to fall by 14:00 07/05/2024, but might not return nearer to normal until 17:00 Wednesday 08/05/2024. Some roads may become impassable, please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding, including Barcombe Mills Road. Flood protection products are recommended to be kept installed in Barcombe, if you have them. We are operating our structures in Barcombe to help keep the river flowing freely and reduce flood risk. We will update this message by 14:00 08/05/2024.

items.description: Wash Dike catchment
items.message:
Levels on Wash Dike have fallen overnight and are no longer a cause for concern. The Wash Dike catchment narrowly missed the worst of the thunderstorms on Monday afternoon, which hit areas of Leeds. No further impactful rainfall is forecast over the next few days and the beck has returned to normal levels. We will continue to monitor the situation.
 
Surface water following yesterday's thunderstorms is likely to affect low spots on roads today. Please avoid walking or driving through flood water, which can contain hidden hazards.

items.description: Freshfield Bridge to Sharpsbridge on the River Ouse
items.message: The River Ouse is very high, but now slowly falling following Monday's rain. Flooding will continue to affect properties of Freshfield Mill Farm, Freshmill and Millers Cottages on Sloop Lane and Bridge Cottage, Sheffield Park. There will also be extensive water in fields and gardens. Roads at Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge will also be affected. No rain is forecast for the next five days, with high pressure predicted to bring settled weather. The river should continue to fall. Flood impacts should ease a little by 17:00 (07/05/2024), but river levels will not return nearer to normal until 11:00 (08/05/2024) on Sloop Lane. River levels near Barcombe might not return to normal until Thursday (09/05/2024). Some roads including Fletching Mill Bridge and Sharpsbridge may become impassable. Please plan to avoid driving through routes vulnerable to flooding suggested in this message. We continue to monitor the levels and forecast. We will update this message by 12:00 on 08/05/2024.
